Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: In CALAMY Out.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: In. It was here. The line is in.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: It was there. It was out. Out

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: In. Tell him Boyle. It was in I say.

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Lights out!

Speaker: crewmen
Dialogue: Watch there! Watch

Speaker: watch captains
Dialogue: - Lifebuoy all's well! - Starboard gangway all's well! - Starboard bow all's well!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How I do hate a lee shore

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: You think we'll have long to wait? JACK  Intelligence reports had her leaving Boston on the 12th, that should put us at least a week ahead.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: She'll be in for a surprise, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: In for a "Surprise". Now that's wit. "In for a Surprise". 'Pon my word I shall have to tell the Doctor.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: I'll try not to, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you have there, Stephen?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The breastbone of a frigate bird. Do you remark its prodigious strength.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I do and I am not in the least surprised, for it reminds me of nothing so much as a ship under sail. See here the bowsprit. Here the mast, and here the backstays running aft.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Ten pounds sixteen ounces. I am preparing a paper for the Royal Society.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I was thinking when our business here is finished, we will have to put in to Recife for provisions. You may care to take a tour round the forests of Brazil, botanizing and collecting specimens. An anaconda or two. A giant cassowary.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I should like it of all things, Jack. Thankyou.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Killick! Killick there! Strong coffee, and light along my topcoat.

Speaker: quartermaster
Dialogue: Six bells and all's well.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Four knots, Sir.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Oi reckon as she's liftin' Sir, if you feels like putting your ad down.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: Starboard gangway ahoy.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: What is it, Vincent?

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: I heard something. A bell.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Native fisherman perhaps.  Mr. Calamy!

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Well. It can't have been a reef marker.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Enemy on the larboard bow! Beat to quarters!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Where away?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Not two miles distant, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr. Hollom?

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: I saw nothing, nor heard anything either. Shall I ask them men to stand down?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Lie down! Everybody lie down!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Run out the guns! Marines to the tops, and get that wounded man below!

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: Shot. There's no shot!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Note the time Mr. Watt.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: She's out of our range, Sir!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Closer, Mr. ALLEN. You must lay me alongside her at pistol-shot.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Fire on the uproll.

Speaker: old sponge
Dialogue: Witchcraft!

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: Never seen the like of it

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Damn and blast you! See to your guns! Fire high! Fire for the masts and rigging!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: More sand on the floor, Mr. Higgins!

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: Wood and Lead! Mr Nagel! Mr Lamb!!

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: Orlop! We're holed!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Davies! Get those bodies overboard!  Mr. Hollom sir!

Speaker: jemmy ducks
Dialogue: Aye, sir!

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: More shot! More cartridge!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: ...wait WAIT! And FIRE!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Belay there ye poxed son of a whore!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: You must go below, Sir, you must let me help you below!

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: It's the rudder.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: It's shot away below the waterline!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Why are we not firing?

Speaker: faster doudle
Dialogue: No steerage.

Speaker: nehemiah slade
Dialogue: We're fish in a barrel

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: He's coming about, Sir.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Should I strike the colours?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I'm afraid there's nothing else for it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Damned if there ain't. We'll tow her.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Sail trimmers away, Warley, make what sail you can!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stern-chasers to fire when she's in range!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: warley
Dialogue: Sharp now with that fancy-line! To the clew line from the reef points, Cully, double up and run her back again!

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: She's gaining on us.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Start the water, carronades over the side.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Pull! Pull for your lives.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Quiet now. No calls, no shouts. Mr. ALLEN, signal the men in the boats to head due east.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Starboard haul. And stroke! Stroke!

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: He's beating inshore.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Keep rowing

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I believe we've lost her, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Pass the word to ship oars

Speaker: lamb
Dialogue: Three feet of water in the hold, Sir, but the pumps are keeping it from gaining.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Very good, Mr. Lamb.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's the butchers bill?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Six dead, thirteen wounded.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Later.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr. Blakeney?

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Just a broken arm, Sir.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I will do everything possible. I know you were close to his father.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Its a scratch.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I will tell you if its a scratch or not. Sit down.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How did he find us Stephen? Seven weeks sailing and he happened in darkness on our exact position. Its uncanny. He really is a phantom

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Unless she was alerted to our presence, and looking for us. JACK Tosh. How could that be?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The French have their spies, in Britain as elsewhere.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I am saying do not imagine it was a lone privateer who did this to us. He is working for Napoleon himself, with access to all that tyrant commands, overtly and covertly. So do not let defeat weigh too heavily upon you.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: ...Call her a frigate? Ha! You ask me she's no more a frigate than a painted Dutchman. More like a ship of the line, a two-decker more'n a frigate.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: One does wonder what manner of hull she has. Our balls seemed to bounce right off her.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: She had the weather-gauge and long eighteens which could hit us beyond our effective range. That's the sum of it

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: And   40 guns to our 28, I counted the muzzle flashes.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: It was an unfair match, no dishonor in defeat no dishonor at all.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Well, we can patch up our main and mizzen the foresail is too far gone so we'll bend our spare.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: At Port Royal we can haul her into dry- dock, and hopefully get her home without...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We're not going home.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: With respect, Captain, she could be half- way to Cape Horn by the time we're repaired and underway.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Then there's not a moment to lose.

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: Can we catch her is the question. And if we do what's different? She'll just hold us off with them long eighteens til she sends us all to the bottom. All for what?

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: I'll tell you for what, matey. She's a privateer, loaded with all the gems of Araby. Think of the gold. Think of the prize-money.

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Hoi there! You men jump to it!

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Heave. And heave. Handsomely now. One long pull. Belay!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Have her placed along the gunwale for now, Mr. Hollar, and the guns moved to that side also.

Speaker: faster doudle
Dialogue: All clear below!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Damn this wind, Mr. Pullings! The Acheron will be making a hundred and fifty miles a day in this.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Aye, but hugging the coast, and stopping to board the odd merchantman

Speaker: lamb
Dialogue: Down. Down. Stop.

Speaker: old sponge
Dialogue: The smaller bit. No. That bit there.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: No. No. Not through my nose!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Its alright. William. You were dreaming.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: You know old Joe, always telling [ ] stories.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Is it true though? [    ] About the last stitch?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Come on, you'll be stitching me in mine first.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Nor any other part of you.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Is it mending, sir?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No, I'm afraid it will not do.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: No. Mamma. Mamma.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: It is the laudanum speaking. You will be a regular Nelson.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Peter? Is that you? I dreamed they cut my arm off.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: You would have died else.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No, that is just blood. These are his brains.

Speaker: slade
Dialogue: Physician he is, not one of your common surgeons.

Speaker: faster doudle
Dialogue: Cured Prince Billy of the marthambles and the strong fives, wouldn't look at you for under ten guineas on land.

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: [   ] Knows his birds and beasts too boyo, show him a beetle and he'll tell you what it's thinking.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Let us be off, Mr. Allen!

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Weigh anchor! All hands to make sail. Mr Hollom!

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Bear a hand there you fellows!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Up and down Sir, thick and dry for weighing.

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Cheerly there in the foretop, our William! T'garnsl sheets! Hands to the braces!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Speed, Mr. Boyle

Speaker: boyle
Dialogue: Ten and a half knots, Sir.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Here we go again: scrape, scrape, screech, screech and never a tune you could dance to, not if you were drunk as Davey's sow.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Is that one I know, or are we breaking new ground?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I am trying to remember that air they played all those years ago at the Governors house in Port Mahon. You remember When we first met. Corelli if I'm not mistaken.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: If that is your "A" you are very much so. This is A.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Or Locatelli. pom pom pom pom

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: All I remember is you being unable to sit in your seat the entire performance.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Aye and you practising apon that poor bishop with your "puddings athwart the starboard Gumbrils" or some such arrant nonsense.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No. That was off Toulon, during the blockade. At our first meeting they played this:

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No. No. Entirely off the mark.   pom-pom- POM I have now

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Or was it something like this....

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And pitch 'em up! It's spars and rigging we want!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Three minutes ten, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Not good enough! We must fire three broadsides to her two. Again!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: 'Spitfire', hop to it.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Again!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Out Tompions... Run out your guns... Prime.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: One minute forty-nine, Sir!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Killick? Killick there. KILLICK appears.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Which it's, Soused Hoggs-Face.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Aah! My favorite.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: With your permission, Sir, Mr. Mowett has composed a short poem in honour of our mission.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Let's hear it, Mr. Mowett.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Our brotherhood, some old, some new. In blood baptized, in strength renewed. In purpose unified and true. All thoughts of home forsaken. Where duty leads us, there we go. Nor rest nor comfort shall we know. Until the unrepentant foe, is boarded sunk or taken

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Aye! Capital! Well said! Hear him, hear him! 'Sunk or taken'...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Aye and when we do take her we shall give her to Tom Pullings as his first command. If he don't die before then. Bumpers up Tom

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: 'To wives and sweethearts'.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: 'To wives and sweethearts'.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: And may they never meet.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Lord Nelson? Yes. I had the honour of serving under him at the Nile.  In fact I dined with him twice, and he spoke to me on both occasions.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: To Lord Nelson.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Lord Nelson!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You see those two weevils, Doctor?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Which would you choose?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But suppose you had to choose?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Then I would choose the right-hand weevil, it has a perceptible advantage in both length and breadth.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: There I have you. You are completely dished. Don't you know in the Navy you must always choose 'the lesser of two weevils'?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: 'Pon my life. He who would pun would pick a pocket. De not smoke it doctor?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Sure there would be some poor thin barren minds that would catch at such a paltry clench.

Speaker: plaice
Dialogue: "...And the righteous shall inherit the earth."

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: You hear that. He said something. Joe spoke! Say something else Joe JOE Handy with that gasket

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: He spoke doctor. Joe plaice spoke

Speaker: midshipmen
Dialogue: Our captain was very good to us. He dipped his prick in phosphorus. It shed a light all through the night. And steered us through the Bosphorus.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: For we've received orders to sail for Old England. Perhaps we shall never more see you again His singing is appreciated by STEPHEN on the quarterdeck.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: What a wonderfully true voice Mr. Hollom does possess.

Speaker: orrage
Dialogue: Come all you thoughtless young men, A warning take by me, And never leave your happy homes to sail the raging sea.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: This one's by Colnett, Sir. He travelled with Captain Cook and carried a pair of Arnott's chronometers.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Couple of the men to see you, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Show them in. The door opens to reveal NAGEL and WARLEY carrying something.

Speaker: nagel
Dialogue: It were Warley's idea, Sir.

Speaker: warley
Dialogue: I thought she were familiar like, then I remembered where I'd seen her - in Boston, during the Peace.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: [   ] In Boston?

Speaker: nagel
Dialogue: If you look here, Sir. One side opens up.

Speaker: warley
Dialogue: Mister Nagel here done it just like I seen her - a third layer 'tween the outer and inner ribbing - diagonal bracing, see?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Just like the U.S. Constitution - our 12 pounders couldn't penetrate except at close range.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Which I was saving for Saluting Day, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Rouse it up, Killick, and a bottle for Mr. ALLEN and me. Let us live whilst we're alive!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: He says they were chased for three days till they finally our-ran her. Forty gun French privateer headed due south.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Capital. Thank him and let us be off.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A Spanish farewell. "May no new thing arrive." New things being generally by their nature bad.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Do you have a manual of exercises sir.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Exercises?

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Physical exercises, to make the left arm as powerful as the right once was.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I think that will happen with usage, at least to a certain extent.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: But not completely. I will never be whole again, will I?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No but you will adapt to your new situation

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: You know my father was a great fighting captain. It was always his expectation I would follow in his footsteps. I worry that with this arm I will now be good for nothing but book learning and philosophy.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Ah. Like me you mean. BLAKENEY  I cannot use a sextant, cannot tie a knot or climb the rigging. Cannot even dress myself. What chance to I have now of even making first lieutenant.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: You have every chance. You hear me every chance. Only the other day I heard the captain singing your praises. Your courage, your fortitude in battle, your skill at logarithms and double elevations whatever they may be. And when you are rated lieutenant you shall have someone to tie your bootlaces for you. Aye and help you with your jacket. Here take my handkerchief. I believe we are summonsed to dinner.

Speaker: warley
Dialogue: Sail on the larboard bow!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Where away?

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Hull down, two points off the larboard beam.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Set studdingsails and top gallants. Then wet the sails and have the idlers placed along the rail.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Is it him, Sir?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Touch wood, Mr. Blakeney. And I fancy she plans to out-run us. Ask Dr. Maturin to join us, he loves a good chase.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Lifelines fore and aft!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Speed, Mr. Calamy?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Twelve knots, Sir!

Speaker: jemmy ducks
Dialogue: We're cracking on, eh?

Speaker: faster doudle
Dialogue: We'll be cracking off presently if he doesn't watch it.

Speaker: slade
Dialogue: No, he knows this ship. He knows what she can take.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: We can just see her topsails. She's made her turn westwards.

Speaker: lamb
Dialogue: I can't vouch for the mizzen Sir, not round Cape Horn. JACK I'll not lose her now. Set a course westwards.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr Hollar, rig preventer backstays. Warps and light hawsers to the mastheads.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: What, Sir?

Speaker: higgins
Dialogue: You reckon Captain will keep chasing him 'round the Horn with every stitch of canvas flying?

Speaker: davies
Dialogue: I reckon he'd chase him to the gates of hell if he has to.

Speaker: plaice
Dialogue: And that's where we're all going if he doesn't take in sail.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Strike the topgallants.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Man overboard!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Swim for the wreckage, man!

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: She's broaching!

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: It's acting as a sea-anchor! We must cut it loose, Sir!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Axes!

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: He's been at it again.

Speaker: black bill
Dialogue: Who's that then?

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: The Jonah.

Speaker: black bill
Dialogue: What Jonah?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The deaths in actual battle are the easiest.  Warley was a casualty of war, as surely as if a French ball had taken him.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: You know that I wear two hats on every voyage. I am the captains particular friend and supporter, but also I am the ships doctor in which later capacity I am party to....

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: On the contrary. I insist on it.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: There is talk below decks of turning back. Or rather that we should have turned back some weeks ago. Of course the men would follow "Lucky Jack" anywhere, and usually in the confident expectation of victory. But that of course is the problem.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What is the problem?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: That you are not accustomed to defeat Jack. That you have taken it too personally. That chasing this larger, faster ship, with its long guns, is beginning to smack of pride 'which goeth before destruction'?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It's not pride nor anything like it, it's a question of duty.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: 'Duty', ah yes. The naval signal for end of discussion.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You can be as 'satiric' as you like, Stephen, but I have my orders. She is attacking our whalers. For why? Without whales we have no boot polish, nor any soap, nor oil for our lamps, not to oil our sabres and muskets. Destroying our whalers could win the war for Napoleon. Which is why we must catch this Acheron. As a man of learning surely you can see that.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: At whatever the cost?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Any whatever cost I choose to pay. And I will calculate that myself, Stephen without reference to your friends in the ward room.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Cast off.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We'll have to go further south, get around this bloody west wind.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: How far south?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: As far as is necessary, Mr. Pullings. The sixtieth parallel if need be.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Then we upon the globes last verge shall go to view the ocean leaning on the sky from thence our rolling neighbours we shall know and on the hidden world securely pry!

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Rise and shine! Show a leg there, tumble up, tumble up - sleepers awake!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Praise be. At last.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Pray what is there to celebrate?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We have made our turn northward, Doctor. We are headed back toward the sun... The officers give a slightly ragged cheer.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Which I was just coming.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I give you... our destination.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The Galapagos Islands.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: 'Pon my word so it is. Look: here's Narborough, Chatham and Hood...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: That's where the whalers are, ain't it Mr Allen. So that's where the Acheron will be headed.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Best bowers chipped... Lot of rust on these forechains... black strake needs another coat.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: That engagement off Recife: his whole gun crew killed and him not a mark on him. Soon as he went up the mizzen mast Warley falls. And whose watch was it when we lost our wind?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A mere thimbleful, Corporal, for scientific purposes only.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Show me where these Doldrums lie?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stephen. Will we never make a sailor of you? The doldrums is a condition, not a region. But you tend to strike 'em here...  ...between the trades, and the sou'easterlies. I hope the Acheron is having it as bad as we are.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Assuming he is heading for the Galapagos, and not some other point in all this vastness?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Come. I'd have thought you'd be delighted to go there. It is said to be a natural paradise

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: In truth I'd be delighted with the merest guano stained rock provided it didn't sway beneath my feet

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, we'll take on food and water once we're there, and as compensation for not having put ashore in Brazil I pledge that during that time, several days at least, you can wander at will, catching bugs and beetles to your heart's delight. You will be the first naturalist to set foot on the islands. That is my solemn promise

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I accept, provided the men have not mutinied and thrown us all overboard before we get there.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mutiny? No. They are already counting their share of the prize money.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Another week of this and they shall gladly give it up for a glass of clean water.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Ach, Stephen. Stephen. Pray stop your bellyacheing. We shall have rain presently, and if not we shall damned well tow ourselves out of this.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Stroke. Stroke...

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: M-a-s-t... mast

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Is that man completely mad?  Mr. Howard, a petrel is not good eating!

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: Were you never a man for sporting, Doctor? Why you could shoot all day in these waters with two men loading!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Blakeney...

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: Rye...

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Swift...

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: Boyle...

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: All right, come on Addison.

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: It's tails. We attack.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Ow ow ow!

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: Yield.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Let go of him.

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: Yield!!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: It's just powder. There wasn't a ball in it, just powder.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: What's wrong? I saved you.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: I didn't need to be saved.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Master at arms! Take that man below and clap him in irons. Mr. Pullings, defaulters at six bells.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The man pushed past you without making his obedience. And yet you said nothing.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: No, Sir, I intended to but the right words just didn't...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: 'The right words'? He failed to salute you. It's deliberate insubordination.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: They don't like me, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They what? Speak up, man!

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: I've tried to get to know the men a bit, Sir, be friendly like, but they've taken a set against me. Always whispering when I go past, giving me looks. But, I'll set that to rights, be tougher on them from now on.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You can't make 'friends' with the foremast jacks, they'll despise you in the end. Nor do you need be a tyrant. It's leadership they want, strength, respect.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: I'm very sorry, Sir. JACK You're what twenty-three, twenty-four?

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Twenty-five next Friday.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You've failed to pass for lieutenant twice. You can't spend the rest of your life as a midshipman.

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: I'll try harder, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, it's an unfortunate business, Hollom. Damned unfortunate.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: 'Article Thirty-Six. All other crimes not capital, committed by any person or persons in the fleet... shall be punished according to the laws, and customs, of the sea.'  Mr. Nagel, you're an old man-of-war's man and yet you failed to salute an officer. You knew what you were doing. Have you anything to say in your defence?

Speaker: nagel
Dialogue: No, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Have his officers anything to say for him?

Speaker: hollar
Dialogue: Seized up, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: One dozen. Bosun's mate, do your duty.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Red hell...

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I was merely remarking that you have always prided yourself on not being a flogging captain and this... JACK I am not a "flogging captain". I have not once rigged the grating on this voyage, not once in twelve thousand miles. Besides, I wager you will find a deal more brutality on land.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I'm not a party to it on land.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well you are party to it on my ship. Men must be governed. Often not wisely I grant you, but there are hierarchies even in nature, as you've often said yourself.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Hierarchies. That is the excuse of every tyrant in history. Of Nero. Of Boneparte.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yes. Fine words I'm sure

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: ...We are not animals and I for one am opposed to authority, that egg of misery and oppression..

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Very fine words Stephen, but In these current circumstances, hard-work and firm discipline is what keeps our little wooden world together.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: And grog I suppose.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Of course. What of it? Of course they have their grog!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The men will have their grog Stephen. It is part of the immemorial tradition of the service

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Well a shameful tradition it is too. To have them pressed from their homes, kept in a permanent state of dull inebriation.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stephen...

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: ...confined for months in a wooden prison, Never more than a few hours sleep and flogged when drunken idleness drives them to....

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I am stating plain facts

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well I will not hear them! From you or anyone. You understand! Things are as they are for good or bad whether or not they have a place in your damned papist philosophy. If you are here to make music then sit down and play. If not be gone, for you have come to the wrong shop for anarchy!

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Are you all right, Hollom?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: He's not sick. He's useless. He's just dodging work.

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: Doctor! The very man.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Mr. Howard, let me beg you, if the men can't eat it or I can't dissect it, please do not shoot every creature you see.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: What did I tell you? The ship's accursed.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What is that abominable noise, for God's sake?

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: I have no idea, Sir.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: You don't think it's the Acheron, Sir?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The enemy cannot come on us without a wind, Mr. Mowett.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I'm sure I've never heard the like.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: [    ] Creature?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: [ ] A manatee. A sea-elephant possibly. Though I have never known one with a cry like this.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Bosun. Fire off some flares.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sergeant, what the devil are you thinking of? Turn the glass and strike the bell.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Perhaps some poor shipwreck?

Speaker: black bill
Dialogue: Duppies make that noise.

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: What's a duppie?

Speaker: black bill
Dialogue: That Warley. Swallow by a fish. Spirit can't get out. Him duppie now.

Speaker: slade
Dialogue: Captain don't even know what that noise be.

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: Doctor neither, and he knows everything.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: Joe here's got the most experience in these matters, and new brains to boot, let's hear it from Joe.

Speaker: plaice
Dialogue: It's the Jonah causing it. That howling thing is a signal to the Phantom-Ship. He's calling it up, don't you see? Every time he's on watch the ship appears. You wait and see, the ghost-ship will appear any time tonight, and take us all straight to the hot-place.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You don't think...?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Mr Hollom. Sir. Try to contain yourself. Hold his head. Mr Hollom. Padeen

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: There's nothing physically wrong with him. He thinks he's been cursed by the 0men.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Then he probably has been. Sailors will abide a great deal, but never a Jonah. It's like a white crow - the others peck it to death.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A 'Jonah'? My God, you believe it too.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I desired to save you the trouble of looking for a cure. No doubt it will all be sorted by the morning.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Mr. Hollom! You gave me such a start. Are you better now?

Speaker: hollom
Dialogue: Much better, thank you.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: I think the creature is going away. HOLLOM I am sure of it.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Man overboard!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The fact is, [   ] not all of us become the men we once hoped we might be. But we are all God's creatures. If some of us thought ill of Mr. Hollom, or spoke ill of him, or failed him in respect of fellowship, then we ask your forgiveness, Lord, and we ask for his.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Strike eight bells.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Give you joy, sir! We have raised the Galapagos!

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: Wot? There must be wimmun. T'ain't natural.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: How extraordinary.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: What, sir?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Those birds!

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: The dragons don't seem to bother 'em.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: They are a type of iguana I should think, and therefore vegetarian. His telescope remains focussed on the cormorants. BLAKENEY is wholly absorbed in the iguanas.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Will you catch one?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Yes. Most certainly. And if we can, some eggs.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: I mean the great lizards.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Ha! There's one going for a swim.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No. Iguanas are land animals.

Speaker: bonden
Dialogue: Not these ones.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: All hands about ship!

Speaker: nehemiah slade
Dialogue: By your leave sir, by your leave.

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: God bless you. Thank you, shipmates.

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: We was coming back for fresh lines, hid in that inlet, yonder. Black-three master. Bit beamy and raised in the stern.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: No swearing on the quarterdeck.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Go on. HOGG ...Then they burnt our bloody ship and headed off, bunch of fugging pirates.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And her course?

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: Maybe a point south of west. Following the rest of the whaling fleet.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: Should we not take on fresh supplies, Sir? Those tortoises...

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Have you forgotten your promise?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Subject to the requirements of the service, Stephen. I could not in all conscience delay for the sake of an iguano or a... giant peccary - interesting no doubt, but of no immediate application.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Well perhaps there's an opportunity to serve both our objectives. As I understand it you mean to go round the end of this long island, then start your voyage. I could walk across it, be on the other side long before...

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I see. So after all this time in your service I must simply be content to form part of this belligerent expedition, hurry past inestimable wonders, bent solely on destruction... JACK ...you forget yourself, sir.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No Jack, You have forgotten your self. You once believed in the rights of each individual man no matter how useless or lowly. But it seems to me now that the long exercise of power has brought you to the point where even a solemn promise...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The promise was conditional.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: ...a promise to a friend of ten years standing who has stood by you and supported you....

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: ...across half the worlds oceans often at risk to his own life

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: ...and we have no time for your damned hobbies, sir!

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Sir, I found a curious beetle walking on the deck.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I'm sure of it.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Were you to have walked all day on the island, you might never have come across it.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: That is more than likely, sure.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: You can have it.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Blakeney.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: No music? That's a shame

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yes, Killick. Just the one.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Martha's vineyard.

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: No, this here's from Boston. I was married there once.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Any road, it's a Yankee barrel.

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: What they call a Bedford Hog in New England.

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: And it's not been in the water more than a week.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: One can't say with any accuracy but...

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: Yes you can. There's no sea chummer on it, and the dowels is sound.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Continue due west, Mr. Bonden.

Speaker: plaice
Dialogue: Have you seen the bird, doctor?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I have not - no bird these many days. What kind of a bird?

Speaker: plaice
Dialogue: A sort of albatross I believe, or perhaps a prodigious great mew. He has been following the ship since... there he is, crossing our wake!

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: My God, man! I'm so sorry. The bird dropped low. I didn't see you there!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Calamy! Get Higgins!  Padeen, Davies, carry the Doctor below.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: It's all right, I am quite capable of walking.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: You will just make it worse... by prodding, Mr. Higgins, it cannot be got at... except by opening me up.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Are you equal to the task?

Speaker: higgins
Dialogue: I'll need to read up on the Doctor's books, like. Study some pictures he has, get my bearings. Be better on land, but I'll manage somehow.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You men get about your business.

Speaker: pullings
Dialogue: It might be the Acheron. If we put on more sail we'd come up with her before nightfall.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: Davies! Slade!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Tell me this wasn't on my account?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Can't have him poking around in your belly without a solid platform to work on.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: All set, Higgins?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Not Higgins. I do this with my own hand.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: [ ] You are sure you have a head and a stomach for this kind of thing?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Then hold my belly, pressing firmly when I give the word.

Speaker: higgins
Dialogue: Aye, she'll patch up nicely, sir.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Easy away, Jack. Handsomely with the retractor. Higgins, look to the Captain, while I swab.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Well sir, Padeen and I have been doing some collecting for you. The beetles each come with a specimen of plant they were found on. Ooops. Catch him, Padeen! There he goes.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: 'Pon my word you have the makings of a true naturalist.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Well sir, perhaps I could combine them, and be a kind of Fighting-Naturalist, like yourself?

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Should you really be up?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Yes. Padeen!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Oh, a week perhaps. There is no great hurry.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: But surely, we must make haste for the Marquesas?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It may not have been the Acheron that we sighted. Nor can we be sure of her destination.  No, I think we shall go home now, before peace breaks out with France, God forbid.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: But how will it sit with the Admiralty? To have spent six months in a fruitless pursuit and then come home empty-handed? JACK "Empty-handed"? Not a bit of it. What about these plants and animals which Blakeney has been collecting? The British museum will need an entire new wing for 'em.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I fear, Jack, you have burdened me with a debt I can never repay.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Tosh. Name a shrub after me. Something prickly and hard to eradicate.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A shrub? I shall name a giant tortoise: Testudo Aubreii!

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Doctor, would you think it very unscientific of me to ride on the back of one of those tortoises.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No, Mr. Blakeney. I would think it an experiment of absolutely vital importance. But afterwards, I do desire to find that flightless cormorant, assuming that is what it is, and that I still have strength enough to catch it.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Sir, you must hurry!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A moment! You're a worse tyrant than any ship's captain.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: You must carry him, Padeen!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I forgot to ask you - did you see your bird?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I did not. My greatest discovery was your phantom.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Indeed it was, I'm sorry...

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Not a bit of it. William and I made a unique discovery.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: A phasmid?

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: It's an insect disguised as a stick.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr. Hollar, rouse up all the yellow paint we have. I want six men with brushes slung over the side.  Doudle!

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: Yessir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Get your sail makers working on this. Sixty yards by five yards with an eyelet every seven feet.

Speaker: doudle
Dialogue: Aye, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr. Calamy!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Aye, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Once we're underway, replace some of the sails with the oldest, most patched set we have.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: They'll be in the afterhold, Sir. I'll need some men to move all the clutter.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Good. Spread it around the foredeck. The more mess the better.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Haul away!

Speaker: hogg
Dialogue: There, Sir. A mainmast toplight.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You've got good eyes, Hogg.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I see. A wolf in sheep in sheep's clothing

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: A phasmid, doctor. It was you what gave me the idea.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I'm not sure a phasmid can be a predator.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No? Well this one is.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: You'll make lieutenant out of this.

Speaker: boyle
Dialogue: He already has. 'Acting' 3rd Lieutenant Peter Calamy.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: [       ] Then I'll see you at the forecastle, 'Lieutenant'.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: That's not your station.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: But naturally I'll board with you?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Will. Captain's orders.

Speaker: rye
Dialogue: She's seen us!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: She's asking us to heave to. Shall I give the order?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, make a show of fleeing upwind, but panicky and disorganized, like a whaler might do.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: May I speak with you, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No saluting, Mr. Blakeney, we're whalers here.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: Mr. Calamy says I am not in the boarding party, I wanted to say -

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I know what you want to say and my answer is no. I promised your mother I would return you in one piece and I have already failed her on that score. You will command a gun and then retire to defend the quarterdeck here with Dr. Maturin.

Speaker: blakeney
Dialogue: But sir -

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: - as any dealt at Trafalgar or Cape St. Vincent.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Three cheers for the Captain.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: I took the liberty, Doctor.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: [    ] Thank you, Killick.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mr. Mowett? [  ] A poem might be in order.

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: A poem, Sir? [   ]  'Oh were it mine with sacred Maro's art, To wake to sympathy the feeling heart,

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What!

Speaker: mowett
Dialogue: ...they were only people of the merchant service, of-course, Sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We have her Mr. Mowett. Strike the Portuguese colours and run up the Jack... Mr. Pullings. Canvas off the gun-ports, and run 'em out. Mr. Howard? Marines away aloft.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Helm's a lee!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Run us down her larboard side then cut across her wake!  Hold fire Mr Pullings! Hold till we're broadside on!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Fire as she bears! Every gun to concentrate on her mainmast!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Now Mr Bonden! Hard a'starboard!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Fire at will!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Boarders away!

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: Look to our quarter-deck!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Where is your captain? Ou est votre capitaine?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Le Capitaine? Where is he?

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: He's dead, sir.

Speaker: calamy
Dialogue: I'll do it. JOE passes him the needle and twine, then they leave him alone.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: John Henry ALLEN... Joseph NAGEL... William Horner... Stephen Winston Boyle... and Lieutenant William Blakeney

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Signal... 'Parole prisoners Valparaiso'...

Speaker: williamson
Dialogue: You mean Lieutenant Pullings, Sir?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No. Captain Pullings.

Speaker: rye
Dialogue: ....then 'Rendezvous Portsmouth. God- speed, Captain Pullings.'

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Shall we begin?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Maybe you did.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: While I was tending the prisoners they told me their doctor died of fever, two weeks ago. There was no doctor on that ship when we boarded it. And I doubt you will find one there now.

Speaker: killick
Dialogue: That's the last of the cheese and like as not they'll leave it seizing to their plates with their tweedly tweedly tweedly.
